titleStmt.title: Dispatch from William Walker to William H. Seward, January 22, 1862

bibl.title: Dispatch from William Walker to William H. Seward, January 22, 1862
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

div1.opener:
Gaboon, Jan 21. 1862.
Hon. W. H. Seward
Washington D.C.
Sir,
div1.p:
I had the honor to write you the 23 Dec. respecting the death of Capt. R.E. Lawlin, an American trader on the River Fernanboz, about 150 miles South of Gaboon. Since the date of my last, Rev. J.M. Preston has been to Camma with the brig. Barque "Minerva," & brought away the goods in the factory & as much other property as he could ship. It is all stered in the Gaboon under my care. A full report of all our proceedings has been made to Mssrs James Bishoop &co. of New York, & I wait the arrival of their agent to deliver the property to him. I have taken considerable responsibility in removing the property & paying & discharging the employees of the factory. But we have no doubt now that the course pursued has been the only one for the interest of the owners.
I have made no sales of property except to pay expenses. I have paid no doubtful debts. We trust that we shall be able to satisfy the Agent who may be sent.

Enclosed please find a copy of the form of the call of allegiance forwarded to their Agency, signed, & certified to by the Commander of Gaboon. As I remarked in my former letter; I do need know how far I am bound to act in regard to duties coming under this Agency. I know not the boundaries of jurisidiction. But I do not wish to act at all, except for the interests of humanity

Allow me to suggest that I find no form of passport. Certificate, Petition Protest, or any paper. No form of any kind, & no table to be filled of shipping or any thing else. If any such duties arise forms are safe, in law & convenient in practice.
div1.closer:
I am, Sir, Your obedient servant
W.M. Walker.
